titleInfo.title: Heavenly Steed, Soaring across the Skies
titleInfo.subTitle: Music for Orchestra

mods:mods.abstract: a heavenly steed, soaring across the skies is a two-movement work for orchestra. The title derives from the Chinese idiom. Chinese people use this idiom to describe a bold, imaginative, unconstrained style. This work intends to create an elevated and cohesive atmosphere connecting two superficially unrelated objects: sky lanterns as a symbol of fortune and the Forbidden City, a palace complex located in Peking (Beijing).The first movement is inspired by a story during the Three Kingdoms period (from 220 to 280 AD). A military strategist of one of the three kingdoms, Zhuge Liang (also known as Zhuge Kongming), invented the sky lantern. When the other Kingdom's army surrounded him in a town, he made sky lanterns to transmit messages to manage an escape from the siege, and he succeeded. Since then, the sky lantern has symbolized hope for success and fortune. Thus, this movement intends to deliver a prayer for hope. It begins with a slow-growing motive decorated by the ostinato in the high register to create a serene atmosphere. The middle section takes inspiration from Igor Stravinsky's "Infernal Dance" from "Firebird", while reimagining it as if this music is written for a video game by featuring repetitive motives and limited polyphony. The driving and relentless section proceeds with the off-beat melodies and disturbs the previous tranquil section. Increased rhythmic pulses and an intense and dramatic atmosphere aims to throw the audience in a place as if a mighty force traps them. Along with the ascending stepwise motive truncated at the end of the middle section, the beginning slow-growing motive returns. The coda depicts sky lanterns flaming while flying to the sky. The second movement is about the Forbidden City. The Yongle emperor of the Ming Dynasty built this marvelous architecture. Since then, the emperors of all dynasties have lived in it. It gives people a sense of mystery and inaccessibility. This movement begins quickly with a short piano introduction accompanied by strings and woodwinds. After a dialogue among woodwind instruments, the main theme is presented in tutti. Influenced by the theme of the film music "The Last Emperor" composed by Ryuichi Sakamoto, the main theme of this movement features a four-note motif with pitches drawn from the pentatonic scale. This motif develops through variations of pitch and rhythmic durations. This movement also fused the features of film music, as it presents various moods through different distinctive musical characters. For example, the middle section uses the extensive virtuosic runs in woodwind parts interrupted by swells creating a sense of exhaustion; in contrast, a slow and lyrical dialogue between clarinet and piano relaxes the tensions between two climaxes, whereas the biggest climax (mm. 125-145) resembles a culmination of a soundtrack from an epic film. This movement aims to make the audience feel the magnificence of the Forbidden City.
